page.title: 02Ingatestone.
page.content:
The rather unusual place-name is probably derived from{'ing at the {stone'}. Ing means homestead or settlement and the 'stone' refers to the glacial erratic, remains of which can be seen to the south of the parish church and in the High Street.
A settlement existed in Saxon times and the name{'Inga'}appears in the Domesday book of 1086.
Much growth of the village was due to its position on the main (originally Roman) road from London to Ipswich and Norwich. Expansion in the last one hundred years or so has been helped by Ingatestone's position on the main railway line between London and East Anglia. Population growth has been particularly rapid since 1951.
